message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that the skin lesions started from an injury and progressed suggests that the most likely pattern is ascending lymphangitis, which means the infection is spreading through the lymphatic vessels. Contact dermatitis would only occur at the site of contact with the irritant, hematogenous dissemination would produce skin lesions throughout the body, and dermatophyte colonization would involve superficial and scaly lesions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The progression of skin lesions from the hand to the shoulder suggests an ascending lymphangitis, where the infection spreads through the lymphatic vessels. The fact that the initial lesion developed from an injury also supports this diagnosis. Contact dermatitis is primarily localized to the site of contact, hematogenous dissemination would show lesions in multiple areas, and dermatophyte colonization would present with itchy, scaly lesions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s skin lesions started from his right hand and progressed to his shoulder, suggesting an ascending lymphangitis. Contact dermatitis is caused by exposure to an irritant or allergen, hematogenous dissemination occurs when bacteria or viruses spread through the bloodstream, and dermatophyte colonization refers to a fungal infection of the skin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that the lesions progressed from the right hand to the right shoulder suggests an ascending lymphangitis pattern, which is typical for a bacterial skin infection. Contact dermatitis is usually confined to the area of contact, hematogenous dissemination suggests systemic involvement, and dermatophyte colonization would not cause necrotic and ulcerative lesions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the lesions spreading from the right hand to the right shoulder suggests ascending lymphangitis. Contact dermatitis would have a more localized area of involvement. Hematogenous dissemination would lead to lesions throughout the body. Dermatophyte colonization would not cause necrotic and ulcerative lesions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The progression of nodular skin lesions from hand to shoulder following an injury suggests an ascending lymphangitis. Contact dermatitis usually occurs just at the site of contact, hematogenous dissemination suggests dissemination of bacteria or fungi through the bloodstream, and dermatophyte colonization refers to fungal infections of the skin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The progression of the nodular lesions from the hand to the shoulder suggests an ascending lymphangitis, which is commonly seen in cases of bacterial skin infections such as cellulitis. Hematogenous dissemination would result in lesions appearing in multiple sites, not in a linear progression. Contact dermatitis and dermatophyte colonization usually have a more localized appearance.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that the skin lesions spread from the right hand to right shoulder suggests that it follows the path of lymphatic vessels, which is characteristic of ascending lymphangitis. Contact dermatitis, hematogenous dissemination, and dermatophyte colonization do not typically follow this pattern of spread.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that the lesions started on the hand and progressed to the shoulder suggests ascending lymphangitis. Contact dermatitis is localized to the site of skin contact with allergens. Hematogenous dissemination would have multiple lesions in different areas. Dermatophyte colonization causes circular, scaly, and itchy lesions, rather than nodular lesions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that the lesion started from an injury and progressed towards the shoulder suggests that it is likely ascending lymphangitis. Contact dermatitis is limited to the area of contact, hematogenous dissemination is typically multiple lesions, and dermatophyte colonization presents differently.
